<gco:CharacterString>This map layer contains tree canopy data for the conterminous United States, in an Albers Equal-Area Conic projection and at a resolution of 100 meters. The tree canopy data were derived from the National Land Cover Database (NLCD) 2001 percent tree canopy data set, a product of the Multi-Resolution Land Characteristics Consortium (MRLC). The MRLC is a multi-agency cooperative effort to study land cover change. The NLCD 2001 is described at http://www.mrlc.gov/nlcd2001.php.</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:abstract>          <gmd:purpose>             <gco:CharacterString>The 100-meter resolution tree canopy data were developed to portray the tree canopy of the United States at 1:1,000,000 scale. They are intended primarily for visual purposes. The original NLCD data should be used for conducting scientific analysis.</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:purpose>          <gmd:status>             <gmd:MD_ProgressCode <gco:CharacterString>NLCD data sets at 30-meter resolution may be downloaded from the MRLC Web site, http://www.mrlc.gov/nlcd01_data.php. Further information on NLCD, related data sets, and land cover research may be found at the online USGS Land Cover Institute http://landcover.usgs.gov/. Pixel values for tree canopy data and their corresponding RGB colors are listed in the color ramp (.clr) file that accompanies the data set. This table shows all tree canopy classes and the RGB color values used to represent them. >Pixel value NLCD 2001 Tree Canopy classes R G B >================================================================================== >1 through 100 Percent tree canopy, 1% through 100% See .clr for RGB's >101, 102, 103 Non-U.S. land 240 235 211 >104 Background U.S. land 104 104 104 >0 Ocean water 193 224 250 Pixel values 1 through 100 represent the percentage covered by tree canopy, as seen from above. Pixel value 101 represents land in Canada or the British Virgin Islands. Pixel value 102 represents land in Mexico or Russia. Pixel value 103 represents land in The Bahamas and Cuba in the southeastern part of the data set. Pixel value 104 represents U.S. land that does not have valid data values. There are no null values in the image. Included with the GeoTIFF are an auxiliary information file (.aux.xml), an image overview file (.ovr), a value attribute database file (.vat.dbf), a .tfw file (more information included below), a .prj file (more information included below), and an Adobe Color Table (.act) file. The contents of the associated world file (.tfw) are: >100.0 >0.0 >0.0 >-100.0 >-2539950.0 >3257950.0 The projection (.prj) file contains the following information: >PROJCS["Albers_NAD83_L48", >GEOGCS["GCS_North_American_1983", >DATUM["D_North_American_1983", >SPHEROID["GRS_1980",6378137.0,298.257222101]], >PRIMEM["Greenwich",0.0], >UNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433]], >PROJECTION["Albers"], >PARAMETER["False_Easting",0.0], >PARAMETER["False_Northing",0.0], >PARAMETER["Central_Meridian",-96.0], >PARAMETER["Standard_Parallel_1",29.5], >PARAMETER["Standard_Parallel_2",45.5], >PARAMETER["Latitude_Of_Origin",23.0], >UNIT["Meter",1.0]] Data set extent in meters (Albers Equal-Area Conic projection) >North 3258000 >West -2540000 >East 2441000 >South 119000 There are no NULL or NODATA values in the GeoTIFF. Instead, all tree canopy values in oceans have been set to zero as part of the masking process. A copy of the land/water mask used in processing is available on request. Information about National Atlas Web services can be found on the Web Map and Web Feature Services page; see http://nationalatlas.gov/infodocs/webservices.html. ; {"gdaId" : 6152789}</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:supplementalInformation>       </gmd:MD_DataIdentification>    </gmd:identificationInfo>    <gmd:contentInfo><!-- translated from eainfo/detailed to MD_CoverageDescription--><gmd:MD_CoverageDescription>          <gmd:attributeDescription gco:nilReason="unknown"/>          <gmd:contentType gco:nilReason="unknown"/>          <!--FGDC content not mapped to ISO.   <gmd:lineage>             <gmd:LI_Lineage>                <gmd:processStep>                   <gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                      <gmd:description>                         <gco:CharacterString>Four tree canopy mosaics at 30-meter resolution were downloaded from the MRLC web site and used to produce tree canopy data files of the conterminous United States, Alaska, Hawaii, and Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. NLCD stores data for the conterminous United States, Alaska, and Hawaii in the same Albers Equal-Area Conic projection used by the National Atlas. Data for Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands (PRVI) were reprojected to match the Albers projection parameters used by the National Atlas for that area. All data were resampled to 100-meter resolution and extents set to match National Atlas neatlines for the four areas. This map layer includes the data file for the conterminous United States. Using the ArcGIS Feature-to-Raster command, a 0/1 land/water mask for the conterminous United States was created from the 1:1,000,000-scale National Atlas coastline, at the same 100-meter resolution and with the same extent as the tree canopy data. The land/water mask was applied to the tree canopy grid with a software routine that used the ArcGIS Multiply command to clip tree canopy values that fell in ocean areas. Tree canopy values were not filled out to the coastline. The Canadian shoreline of the Great Lakes was extracted from NSFH_2008 and incorporated into the data set used to generate the land/water mask. Ocean areas were set to a pixel value of 0. The land/water mask is available on request. In the conterminous United States tree canopy data set, non-data pixels were set to separate values: 101 for Canada, 102 for Mexico, and 103 for The Bahamas and Cuba. In Alaska: 101 for Canada and 102 for Russia. In PRVI: 101 for the British Virgin Islands.</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:description>                      <gmd:dateTime>
